results.title: The Snails = Les Escargots
results.creator_credit: Societe des Films d'Art et de Culture
results.brief_description: Animated science fiction fantasy about man’s inability to learn from his mistakes. Depicts a peasant who discovers that his tears will make his crops grow, but snails appear, consume the crops and become monstrous creatures. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Societe des Films d’Art et de Culture

results.title: The Snails = Le'escargots
results.creator_credit: Societe des Films d'Art et de Culture and Rene Laloux
results.brief_description: An animated story about man’s inability to learn from his mistakes. A market gardener’s plants are dying and his tears revive the plants, but snails quickly appear, consume his crop, and become mammoths. They move about destroying all, but the city is rebuilt and the cycle begins again.

results.title: The Smoking machine
results.creator_credit: J.B. Holmes, Realist Films and Sarah Erulkar
results.brief_description: A group of young children are approached by an older friend Jim, who offers them a choice. Disgusted with the taste and curious about why people smoke they set out in their neighbourhood and study people who smoke. They stumble across a smoking machine and examine its insides to discover what smoking does to the inside of one’s body.

results.title: The Smithsonian Institution
results.creator_credit: IBM, Charles Eames and Ray Eames
results.brief_description: As close to a dramatic feature as the Eameses ever got in this tribute commissioned for the 125th anniversary of the Smithsonian Institution. Dramatises the early history and development of the Smithsonian Institution, which began with the unusual bequest of Englishman James Smithson. Traces the growth of the Smithsonian from a small research centre and repository of museum collections to its modern position. In addition to the dramatic recreation, this film also uses paintings, sculpture and other works of art to recreate the period. Narrated by Alistair Cooke, prologue by Walter Cronkite, advice and counsel by John Houseman. Appearing are Ronald Long, Arnold Moss and Alan Napier.

results.title: The Smile and the interweave: Madonna, child and Saint Anne (circa 1500-1515) Leonardo da Vinci, Vinci 1452-Amboise 1519
results.creator_credit: Alain Jaubert, Delta Image, La Sept, FR3 and Musée du Louvre
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Palettes”.
In the center Saint Anne: she wears her hair braided, her eyes are lowered and she is smiling. Seated on her knees, the Virgin Mary, wearing a low-necked dress, is leaning toward the infant Jesus. This mysterious painting is a fine example of all the qualities, which make Leonardo da Vinci’s work unique and recognisable. The video explores Leonardo’s techniques, the chromatic range he used, the composition and symbolism of the picture as well as its history and the life of its creator, whose “hand could not match his intellect”, resulting in very few completed works.

results.title: The Smell of war
results.creator_credit: Granada Television International and Julia Spark
results.brief_description: A segment from the television program “History in action”, this video is aimed at an audience of junior high school students through to adults. It is an investigation of the conditions and events leading to the spark that set off World War I. Includes rare archival footage.
results.description: A segment from the television program “History in action”, this video is aimed at an audience of junior high school students through to adults. It is an investigation of the conditions and events leading to the spark that set off World War I. Includes rare archival footage.

results.title: The Smash
results.brief_description: Harry (Stephen Blackburn of Tim and Debbie) is a member of a pop group - The Smash. Unfortunately his careless driving ends with an accident resulting in injuries to himself and his lead singer, and excessive damage to his car and a parked car. This program teaches about the legal and insurance consequences of car accidents.

results.title: The Small poppies
results.creator_credit: J D Productions, Artists Who Wash Cars and Robert Mack
results.brief_description: For the 2000 Dublin Theatre Festival, Sydney’s Company B Belvoir were invited to perform a production of “The Small Poppies”. This documentary traces the play’s rehearsal of a comic work, pitched at young children, about experiencing the first day at primary school. The cast is a bevy of well-regarded Australian actors, including David Field, Julie Forsyth, Deborah Mailman, Rebecca Massey, Arky Michael and Geoffrey Rush. Interviews are conducted with members of the audience, mostly small children, who humorously reminisce about their first day at school and consider why people create works and attend the theatre. Geoffrey Rush discusses theatre, his history as an actor, and desire to create a piece of theatre, back in 1986, about the first day at school, with playwright David Holman. Interviews with the cast, Holman and director Neil Armfield, are interspersed with black and white stills of Rush and Holman, from 1986, researching, visiting schools and observing young children first hand, much of which formed the finished play. Displaying rehearsals, discussions and processes that attribute to a successful play, makes for a fascinating view of collaborative art, and this documentary shows extended footage from the Dublin performance and what appears to be an extremely amusing and affecting work.

results.title: The Small one
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney Educational Media Company and Don Bluth
results.brief_description: The Small One is a donkey, aptly named due to his size. Owned by a little boy, the donkey must be sold as he cannot match the workload of the other donkeys. Heartbroken, the boy takes the donkey into town to sell him, his main concern being to find him a good owner. The boy is disheartened when no-one is interested in his donkey, until he meets a man who has a special job for the small one- to carry his wife to Bethlehem. Based on the book by Charles Tazewell.
